Shaoxing 312300 China bJoint R&D Center of Zhejiang University of Technology and Zhejiang Noah Fluorochemical Co., Ltd., Shaoxing 312300, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Industrial Catalysis, State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, Zhejiang University of Technology, Chaowang Road 18, Hangzhou, Zhejiang 310014, China. Institute of Industrial Catalysis State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology Zhejiang University of Technology Chaowang Road 18 Hangzhou Zhejiang 310014 China Transforming potent greenhouse gasses, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) to hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs) is an environmentally friendly and low energy input route compared with traditional incineration method. During the conversion process, Lewis acidity of the catalysts play a vital role in the activity. Here, inspired by the fluorinated metal oxide, a novel nonmetallic catalyst SiC was fabricated via sequentially mechanochemical treatment and fluorination. With series characterizations, it demonstrated that on the super surface of SiC, there are thin layers of graphite, COOH species, SiO2 and Si4C4-xO2 substrates. Through the mechanochemical treatment, the layers of graphite, COOH species and partial SiO2 could be grinded off. Hence, the exposed SiO2 residue could be removed via the fluorination by HFC-152a and HF forming volatile SiF4. At the same time, the transition layer, Si4C4-xO2 was fluorinated to Si4C4-xF2 accompanied with enhanced Lewis acidity. As a result, the activity of the treated SiC was significantly superior than the unmilled SiC. These findings provide a feasible way to develop the catalytic performances of nonmetallic catalysts for the dehydrofluorination. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords SiC Mechanochemical treatment Fluorination Lewis acidity Dehydrofluorination Data availability Data will be made available on requests. 1 Introduction Refrigerants can be divided into four generations according to their popularity and the environmental performance [1–4]. The first and second generations of refrigerants are constituted by well-known chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and hydrochlororfluorocarbons (HCFCs), respectively. They have been entirely phased out acted as refrigerants due to the intensive ozone depletion potential (ODP). It has been confirmed that during the degradation of CFCs and HCFCs in the atmosphere, the produced Cl· and related radicals facilitate the decomposition of O3 into stoichiometric O2 molecules, leading to the formation of ozone holes at the Earth's poles [1]. Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), considered as the third generation of refrigerants, have been expected as the perfect substitute of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), given that the ozone depletion potential (ODP) of zero. In past decades, HFCs have been widely used as refrigerants, blowing agents, propellants and extinguishants, and so on [5, 6]. However, the researchers have confirmed that HFCs is one kind of potent greenhouse gasses and has been regulated by Kigali Amendment, the latest amendment of Montreal Protocol [7–9]. Comparatively, the fourth generation of refrigerants, hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs) is considered as the environmentally friendly alternatives of HFCs. HFOs pose no impact on stratospheric ozone (ODP of 0) as well, and especially, the lifetime of HFOs is significantly shorter than HFCs, due to the unstable C=C. Correspondingly, HFOs possess much lower global warming potential (GWP) than HFCs [10,11]. Consequently, it is necessary to develop suitable routes to dispose the surplus HFCs, including high-temperature combustions, co-pyrolysis with hydrocarbons, plasma etching and catalytic dehydrofluorination etc. [5,7,12-14]. Among these methods, catalytic dehydroflucarbons is the most promising process, as this route converts HFCs to high value added HFOs [15–18]. Except for refrigerants, HFOs are also the important monomers of series fluoropolymers. Fluoropolymers find wide applications in industry due to the excellent chemical inertness, wear-resisting, weather fastness, etc. [19,20]. At present, it is well accepted that Lewis acid sites are the active centers to active the highly stable C-F bond during dehydrofluorination reactions [21–23]. Consequently, metal fluorides (AlF3, MgF2) or fluorinated metal oxide (Cr2O3) are used in the reaction which can survive from the corrosive environment (formation of HF) [18,23-26]. Whereas, for dehydrofluorination, there exists a trade-off relation between activity and stability. The strong Lewis acid sites are not only the active sites, but they also account for the carbon deposition [11,21]. Li et al. reported that the amount of weak Lewis acid sites showed a good linear relation with catalytic activity for HFC-143a dehydrofluorination. However, strong Lewis acidity deactivated rapidly due to the formation of coke [21]. Except for metal fluoride catalysts, the catalytic performances of nonmetallic catalysts are scarcely investigated. Silicon carbide (SiC) is a typical ceramic material with strong corrosion resistance, and high thermal conductivity [27–30]. Due to its excellent stability and thermal conductivity, SiC was selected as the support of catalysts in our precious work [31]. We found that F element of AlF3 had an interaction with Si of SiC, then the catalytic activity and stability were significantly enhanced for the supported AlF3 catalyst. Unexpectedly, lots of work confirmed that there were layers of SiO2 during the fabrication of SiC or oxidized SiC. Hornetz et al. investigated the surface composition of oxidized SiC [32]. At the surface of the bulk SiC, there presented a transition layer between SiO2 and SiC, and constituted by Si4C4- x O2 (x < 2). The layer thickness was about 1 nm at the Si-(001) surface. Afterward, at the surface of SiO2, graphite and some SiC4O4 were detected. Motivated by the enhanced Lewis acidity of the fluorinated metal oxide [33], it is reasonable to deduce that the fluorinated nonmetal oxide might also exhibit quasi Lewis acidic properties as well. However, removal of the surface graphite and SiO2 are the prerequisites to implement the fluorination of Si4C4- x O2 or SiC4O4. Fortunately, mechanochemical treatment (MCT) was proved as the most economical and convenient method to the exfoliation of the graphite [34,35]. In this work, the catalytic performance of SiC with or without MCT and fluorination was systematically investigated. The effects of MCT were measured by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, EPR. Especially, the evolution of the surface composition and the element state after the MCT and fluorination were detailed investigated via the XPS characterization. Since the Lewis acid sites were the active centers for the dehydrofluoriantion, the change of the acidic properties of SiC before and after the treatment was confirmed by the NH3-TPD and Py-IR. Considering that the acid intensity of fluorinated SiC is weaker than fluorinated metal oxide, the dehydrofluorination of 1,1-difluoroethane (HFC-152a) to VF (vinyl fluoride, CH2 CHF) is selected as the probe reaction, for which weak Lewis acidity is strong enough to catalyze the destruction of stable C-F bond in HFC-152a. 2 Experiment 2.1 Regents and chemicals Silicon carbide (SiC, 99.0% with particle size between 0.5 and 0.7 μm) were purchased from Aladdin Company, Shanghai, China, without any pretreatment. HFC-152a (>99.0%) was provided by Juhua group corporation. 2.2 Mechanochemical treatment (MCT) of SiC A planetary ball-mill (KE-0.4 L, Qidong Honghong Equipment Co., Ltd.) containing four pots (0.4 L) was used for the MCT of SiC at room temperature. Milling balls, together with the sample (5.55 g) to be treated, were sealed in the pots. The number of the balls with the diameters of 15, 8, and 5 mm were 2, 10 and 10, respectively. The material of the pots and milling balls are corundum. The rotation rate of each pot was 300 rpm and the rotation time was 1, 2 and 4 h, respectively. The obtained catalysts are denoted as SiC, SiC-xh, where x represents the milling time. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The samples were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Thermo ARL X'TRA diffractometer (Cu-Kα radiation). The operated voltage and current were 40 kV/40 mA, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB210 (VG Co., monochromatized micro-focused Mg Ka X-ray source) to study components as well as the effect of milling on the binding energy of the elements located on the SiC surface. Specific surface area of the SiC and milled SiC were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. Before N2 adsorption, the samples were pretreated under 200 °C to remove the impurities. The data was calculated by BET method. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were recorded at room temperature on a Bruker EPR alpha 300–10/12 spectrometer, equipped with an on-line computer for data treatment. The acidity of the SiC and milled SiC was measured by Py-IR (Nicolet 6700) within 4000–400 cm−1. Before the test, the samples were heated under an infrared lamp at 100 °C for 1 h to expel the adsorbed water. Moreover, the acidic properties were also confirmed by NH3-TPD (Autochem 2019). Before the detection, the samples were pretreated at 500 °C with He. Then the temperature was decreased to 100 °C and NH3 was input. After 30 min, the He was input to exclude the surplus NH3, and the temperature was increased to 400 °C at 5 °C min−1. 2.4 Pre-fluorination of SiC-2h The fluorination conditions were as follows: 2 g milled SiC put to the isothermal region of the fixed bed reactor. Firstly, under N2 atmosphere (10 mL/min), the temperature of the catalysts layer was increased to 200 °C at 10 °C/min. Then the flow rate of N2 was changed to 5 mL/min, meanwhile, 5 mL/min of HF was introduced to the reactor as well. After fluorinated 6 h, the catalysts were obtained and denoted as SiC-2h-HF. 2.5 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic experiments were conducted on a fixed-bed reactor (i.d. of 8 mm) at atmospheric pressure. 2 mL of catalysts were loaded into the reactor with a thermal couple inserted into the middle of the catalysts to detect the actual reaction temperature (300 °C). The total flow rate was controlled at 10 mL (HFC-152a/N2 of l/1, GHSV of 300 h−1). In order to minimize the corrosion of HF to gas chromatograph (GC), the output gasses of the reactor were firstly treated by an aqueous KOH solution and then the left gasses were analyzed by a GC (Jiedao GC1690) equipped with a PoraPLOT Q column and TCD (thermal conductivity detector). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effects of milling on SiC catalysts In order to clarify the effects of milling on the physicochemical properties of SiC, series of characterizations were made. The compositions of the investigated SiC were identified by XRD analysis (Fig. 1 (a)). Despite the changed diffractive intensities of some peaks, the bulk phase of the SiC-2h is consistent with primitive SiC, which mainly comprised by α-SiC. While Dong et al. found that new phase of SiC were formed after sole milling [36]. The different results might be triggered by the diverse milling conditions. During the MCT process, there exists strong mechanical force between stainless-steel balls and SiC, as well as high temperatures caused by the intensive collision and rotation, then it is reasonable to speculate that crystal distortion emerged for the SiC-2h. The partial enlargement of the XRD spectrograms is shown in Fig. 2 (b). After the milling treatment, the diffractive peaks of SiC-2h is slightly shifted to high angles, indicating that mild lattice distortion is presented in the SiC-2h. Consequently, oxygen vacancies can be generated during the lattice distortion. As shown in Fig. 2, for SiC, no signal of free electrons is detected. Comparatively, the signals located at g = 2.0047 caused by oxygen vacancies can be well distinguished. Furthermore, the intensity of the signals increases with milling time, which indicates more oxygen vacancies can be created via milling. It has to note that during the high temperature calcination, partial oxidation of SiC occurred, then oxygen vacancies are originated from the oxidative products [32]. The TEM micrographs of unmilled and milled SiC (SiC-2h) are given in Fig. 3 (a-b). For the starting material, the particle shape looks like sausage, and the size is about 0.8 μm. While, regarding to the SiC-2h, it can be clearly seen that the grains become smaller with unregular morphologies. Moreover, several crevices appeared in the milled SiC. Even though, the particles size of SiC-2h is smaller than SiC, the specific surface areas of these samples exhibit no clear difference (Fig. 3(c)). The textural properties of SiC and milled SiC were collected in Table S1. 3.2 The effects of milling and fluorination on lewis acidity As the Lewis acid sites are the active centers for the dehydrofluorination, the generation of the Lewis acidity should be well investigated. Fig. 4 descripts the Py-IR spectra of pristine SiC, milled SiC (SiC-2h) and the spent SiC-2h. In order to quantify the amounts of Lewis and Brønated acid sites, curve fitting treatment was executed on the representative catalysts (Fig. 4 and Table 1 ). For the pristine SiC and SiC-2h, it can be detected that no improvement of Lewis acidity is observed after milled treatment (Table 1), as well as the NH3-TPD results in the Fig. 5 (a). Therefore, it can conclude that milled process has no impact on the Lewis acidity. Whereas, referring to the spent SiC-2h, compared with SiC-2h, the increase of Lewis acidic amounts located at 1447–1450 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1, which are both assigned to Lewis acidity is well distinguished [15,17,37,38]. Besides, the peak centered at 1491 cm−1 contributed to Brønated and Lewis acidity is also apparently improved. Especially for the spent SiC-2h, there appears a weak peak at 1542 cm−1 assigned to the Brønated acid site. It might be generated via the hydrolysis of surface CxHyOz or Si-OH. From Fig. 5(a), it noted that there appeared an NH3 desorption perk centered at 200 °C for the spent SiC-2h, meaning that new acidic sites are fabricated during the fluorinated process. In order to further demonstrate that fluorination by HFC-152a or HF could enhance the Lewis acidity of SiC-2h, disproportionation reaction of monochlorodifluoromethane (HCFC-22) over SiC-2h and spent SiC-2h is compared, which generally used as the probe reaction to determine the Lewis acidity [39]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the activity of spent SiC-2h is distinctly higher than SiC-2h, which is consistent with the results of Py-IR spectrum. 3.3 Evolution of Lewis acidity Consequently, the evolution of the surface acidity over milled SiC and reacted SiC is carefully investigated by XPS to better elucidate the generation of Lewis acidity, since the XRD results showed that the bulk structure of spent SiC-2h is still α-SiC as well (Figure S1). Fig. 6 shows the Si 2p and C1s XPS spectra of SiC, SiC-2h and spent SiC-2h, and the corresponding O1s and F1s XPS spectra are presented in Figure S3. For the pristine SiC, the surface is mainly constituted by the C, Si and O elements (Figure S2). The comparatively amounts of each element is summarized in Table S2. Based on the previous reports, the resolution spectra of C, Si, O and F can be deconvoluted into several peaks. Thus, for convenience, the identification of each component is collected in Table 2 . Assignment of C 1 s according to level shifts. Two obvious peaks located at 282.4 and 284.7 eV are assigned to the SiC and graphite, respectively [40,41]. The relatively smaller peak centered at 283.4 eV is fitted to the interface oxide Si4C4- x O2 [32]. It is apparently suggested that, near the graphite, there exists a shoulder peak in the higher binding energy region. The composition of this line is complex, including small amounts of Si4C4O2 produced via the oxidation of Si4C4- x O2, and partial hydrocarbons adsorbates and their oxidation products C x H y O z . The highest binding energy at 288.9 eV is contributed by the COOH species [42]. Assignment of Si 2p according to level shifts. The spectrum of Si 2p is composed of less lines than C 1 s. The Si 2p core level shift at 100.3 eV belongs to the SiC [43,44]. Corresponding to the C 1 s, the peak focused on 100.6 eV is ascribed to the interface oxidation Si4C4- x O2 [32]. As noted, the higher binding energy at 103.0 eV is caused by the SiO2 layers [36,45,46]. Assignment of O 1s according to level shifts. The O 1s of SiC and SiC-2h catalysts is mainly comprised by one peak. Owing to the closely binding energy of specific carbonic (C x H y O z ) and silicic oxide (Si4C4- x O2), consequently, it is difficult to distinguish the specific peaks of each oxide species. For the spent SiC-2h, there appears a new peak at 533.3 eV, which can be assigned to the absorbed H2O according to reported works [47]. Because, during the rection between SiO2 and fluorinated-gasses, H2O can be produced simultaneously. From Fig. 6(a), it can see that compared with SiC, the peak positions of the milled SiC (SiC-2h) all shift to lower binding energy, which might be caused by the intensive destruction by the ball milling leading to the weak interaction of chemical bond existed in SiC. Moreover, it is clearly noted that the peaks assigned to COOH species vanished. Meantime, the peak area of C x H y O z , Si4C4O2 and graphite decreases. Especially for the peak belonging to the graphite, the decreased percent is 42%. Through analysis of the Si 2p spectrum of SiC and SiC-2h, similar phenomena can be detected. Firstly, the peak position of each specific peak is also moved to lower binding energy range, consistent with the oxygen vacancies in Fig. 2. Furthermore, the peak area of SiO2 component declines. Therefore, based on above results, it can deduce the relative position of every component. The species assigned to the vanished peak and the largely declined peak area are distributed near the super surface of the SiC, including the partial graphite, COOH, followed by C x H y O z and SiO2 species. The position of interface oxide is located between SiO2 and SiC. Thus, the area variation of this species is neglected. In addition, as expected, the peak area of SiC-2h is smaller than SiC (Table 2 and Figure S3 (a)). While, for the spent SiC-2h, the peak positions of specific carbonic and silicic components are all shifted to higher binding energy region again, which is caused by the fluorination of SiC surface during the reaction, since the amounts of F species are significantly increased (Table S2). For the Si 2p spectrum of spent SiC-2h, the peak ascribed to SiO2 disappeared, which is caused by the readily reaction between SiO2 and HF or HFC-152a. Since the binding energy of Si4C4- x O2 is shift from 100.6 eV to 101.3 eV, then it indicates that the partial Si4C4- x O2 species have been fluorinated to Si4C4- x F2 species, given the largely reduced O species contents as shown in Figure S3(a), Table 2 and Table S2. Especially, due to the vanishment of SiO2, the new fabricated Si4C4- x F2 species can directly expose to the reactive molecules. The evolution of Si4C4- x O2 components (283.7 eV) in C 1 s spectra of spent SiC-2h can achieve the same conclusion. Besides, owing to the vanishment of graphite via milling and SiO2 via milling and fluorination, the peak areas belong to SiC in C 1 s and Si 2p are slightly increased. Figure S3(b) shows the F 1 s spectra of spent SiC-2h. The core level shift at 685.3 eV is attributed to the Si4C4- x F2, and the binding energy centered at 687.0 eV is caused by the C x H y F z species. In summary, the evolution of the Lewis acidity is facilitated by the initially milling and followed by the fluorination, as shown in Scheme 1 . During the milling process, the entire COOH layers, partial graphite and SiO2 layers are peeled off, leading to the SiO2 surface directly exposing to the HF or HFC-152a. Consequently, the outer SiO2 layers are readily completely reacted with HF and HFC-152a. Meantime, the interface oxide Si4C4- x O2 is fluorinated to Si4C4- x F2 species. Considering the enhanced Lewis acidity after the reacted SiC-2h, as well as the strong electronic negativity of F species, then, it can conclude that the generated Lewis acidic properties is attributed to the new generated Si4C4- x F2 species, which located at the outer surface after the vanishment of SiO2. 3.4 Catalytic evaluation Fig. 7 (a) shows the conversion activity of HFC-152a over the as-made catalysts via MCT. As expected, it can be clearly seen that the catalytic activity of pure SiC is nearly zero, which means that SiC does not possess any Lewis acidity at all, consistent with the results of NH3-TPD (Fig. 5(a)) and Py- IR (Fig. 4). While, the conversion of HFC-152a for the milled SiC catalysts are distinctly superior than untreated SiC. Initially, the activities of milled SiC increase with milling time and then keep nearly constant (40%). Furthermore, it can observe that the activities of SiC-xh catalysts all firstly decrease with time on stream, and then reach stable states. It has to emphasize that the change tendency of SiC-xh catalysts is totally different from the well-known fluorinated metal oxide, for which it presented an inductive period to improve the HFCs conversion, [23,25,48-50]. The activity comparation of milled SiC and traditional Al2O3 is shown in Figure S4. Within 100 h, SiC-2h exhibits better catalytic stability than fluorinated Al2O3. The decreased activity for the latter is due to the strong Lewis acidity which could lead to coke deposition. Besides, the comparation between SiC-2h and other reported work are collected in Table S4. Fig. 7(b) shows the reaction rate of the series SiC catalysts. As expected, it presents the same activity sequence as the conversion. In addition, it can confirm that milling of 2 h is the optimal milling time. In order to verify whether the initial decline of activity for SiC-2h is caused by the reaction of HFC-152a with impurities (such as SiO2) in SiC, the ratio of produced VF with converted HFC-152a is calculated based on the peak area gained by the on-line GC, respectively. From Table S3, it demonstrates that the calculated ration is lower than 1 during the inceptive 8 h. Moreover, if the SiC-2h was pre-fluorinated with HF before the activity test, the initial decrease of HFC-152a conversion could be eliminated (Figure S5). Correspondingly, it can conclude that during the activity declining period, it occurs two reactions, one is the reaction between HFC-152a with impurities, accompanied with the fluorination of SiC since the enhanced activity of SiC-2h compared with SiC based on the results of XPS analysis. The other is the dehydrofluorination of HFC-152a. In addition, the selectivity of desired products VF is nearly 100% when the reaction reaches the steady range, which is not shown here. 4 Conclusion In this paper, a novel nonmetal catalyst for dehydrofluorination was developed. Compared with unmilled SiC, the milled SiC exhibits higher dehydrofluorination activity of HFC-152a, improved nearly 40%. Through the Py-IR and disproportionated reaction of HCFC-22, it can confirm that the Lewis acidity of spent SiC-2h is enhanced. Since the bulk structure of spent SiC-2h is still maintained, the evolution of SiC surface is carefully investigated by the XPS spectra. It can conclude that the milled process is feasible for the exposure of SiO2 layers, and then the following fluorination can remove the SiO2 and fluorinate the interface oxide Si4C4- x O2 to Si4C4- x F2 species. Consequently, the Lewis acidity is formed on the outer surface of SiC to promote the dehydrofluorination activity of HFC-152a. coredata.dc:description: Transforming potent greenhouse gasses, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) to hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs) is an environmentally friendly and low energy input route compared with traditional incineration method. During the conversion process, Lewis acidity of the catalysts play a vital role in the activity. Here, inspired by the fluorinated metal oxide, a novel nonmetallic catalyst SiC was fabricated via sequentially mechanochemical treatment and fluorination. With series characterizations, it demonstrated that on the super surface of SiC, there are thin layers of graphite, COOH species, SiO2 and Si4C4-xO2 substrates. Through the mechanochemical treatment, the layers of graphite, COOH species and partial SiO2 could be grinded off. Hence, the exposed SiO2 residue could be removed via the fluorination by HFC-152a and HF forming volatile SiF4. At the same time, the transition layer, Si4C4-xO2 was fluorinated to Si4C4-xF2 accompanied with enhanced Lewis acidity. As a result, the activity of the treated SiC was significantly superior than the unmilled SiC. These findings provide a feasible way to develop the catalytic performances of nonmetallic catalysts for the dehydrofluorination.
coredata.dc:title: Evolution of Lewis acidity by mechanochemical and fluorination treatment of silicon carbide as novel catalyst for dehydrofluorination reactions
